prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS_1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The science goal is to search for [CII] in the redshift range 6.74-6.9 in the two brightest sources from Smit et al. 2015 over the CANDELS-COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect a FWHM of 200-250 km/s so the coarsest spectral resolution is sufficient.

We do no want to resolve these sources, which are ~1.3 arsec in diameter, but one source is fairly close to a neighbouring source. We therefore ask for a resolution between 1.3 and 1.6 arcsecond for these sources.

We predict the luminosity of the [CII] line at 1900.5 Ghz in our two COSMOS sources based on the empirical relation from De Looze et al. (2011) between [CII] luminosity and SFR. We use the flux in the H-band to calculate the UV-luminosities and use the Kennicutt (1998) relation to convert this to SFRs of ~22 M/yr, using the lower-limit case where the UV light is unattenuated by dust. Assuming a redshift of z~6.8 the observed flux in the [CII] line is 0.23 Jy km/s using the relation from Solomon, Downes & Radford (1992). For reference, the sources targeted by Capak+2015 have [CII] line fluxes in the range 0.29-1.95, for SFRs in the range 18-169, indicating our numbers are realistic.
Furthermore assuming the typical FWHM for the LBGs in Capak+2015 of 250 km/s, we derive peak fluxes of ~1.1 mJy (taking into account that our sources are unresolved). To properly sample the line, we require a S/N=3 in 50 km/s bands (S/N>5 for the integrated line), we therefore ask for a RMS of 0.36 mJy. We cover the >99% redshift probability window in only 3 tunings. We have investigated the option of performing a line scan but we find that, for these short scans, searching for the line in separate science goals is more efficient.
While our main science goal is to detect [CII], we will also put upper limits on the dust content and determine if indeed UV selected high-redshift galaxies have very low levels of dust, i.e. LIR<~0.1LUV (Capak+2015).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS_3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The science goal is to search for [CII] in the redshift range 6.45-6.59 in the two brightest sources from Smit et al. 2015 over the CANDELS-COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect a FWHM of 200-250 km/s so the coarsest spectral resolution is sufficient.

We do no want to resolve these sources, which are ~1.3 arsec in diameter, but one source is fairly close to a neighbouring source. We therefore ask for a resolution between 1.3 and 1.6 arcsecond for these sources.

We predict the luminosity of the [CII] line at 1900.5 Ghz in our two COSMOS sources based on the empirical relation from De Looze et al. (2011) between [CII] luminosity and SFR. We use the flux in the H-band to calculate the UV-luminosities and use the Kennicutt (1998) relation to convert this to SFRs of ~22 M/yr, using the lower-limit case where the UV light is unattenuated by dust. Assuming a redshift of z~6.8 the observed flux in the [CII] line is 0.23 Jy km/s using the relation from Solomon, Downes & Radford (1992). For reference, the sources targeted by Capak+2015 have [CII] line fluxes in the range 0.29-1.95, for SFRs in the range 18-169, indicating our numbers are realistic.
Furthermore assuming the typical FWHM for the LBGs in Capak+2015 of 250 km/s, we derive peak fluxes of ~1.1 mJy (taking into account that our sources are unresolved). To properly sample the line, we require a S/N=3 in 50 km/s bands (S/N>5 for the integrated line), we therefore ask for a RMS of 0.36 mJy. We cover the >99% redshift probability window in only 3 tunings. We have investigated the option of performing a line scan but we find that, for these short scans, searching for the line in separate science goals is more efficient.
While our main science goal is to detect [CII], we will also put upper limits on the dust content and determine if indeed UV selected high-redshift galaxies have very low levels of dust, i.e. LIR<~0.1LUV (Capak+2015).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CLASH_1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The science goal is to search for [CII] in the redshift range 6.74-6.9 in the brightest lensed source from Smit et al. 2014 from the CLASH survey.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect a FWHM of 200-250 km/s so the coarsest spectral resolution is sufficient.
We do no want to resolve this source, which is 1.3 arsec in diameter and well isolated. We therefore ask for a resolution between 1.3 and 2.0 arcsecond.

We predict the luminosity of the [CII] line at 1900.5 Ghz in our three sources based on the empirical relation from De Looze et al. (2011) between [CII] luminosity and SFR, using a magnification due to the foreground cluster of 2.5x. We use the flux in the H-band to calculate the UV-luminosities and use the Kennicutt (1998) relation to convert this to an SFR of ~17 M/yr, using the lower-limit case where the UV light is unattenuated by dust. Assuming a redshift of z~6.8 the observed flux in the [CII] line is ~0.6 Jy km/s (de-lensed 0.24 Jy km/s) using the relation from Solomon, Downes & Radford (1992). For reference, the sources targeted by Capak+2015 have [CII] line fluxes in the range 0.29-1.95, for SFRs in the range 18-169, indicating our numbers are realistic.
Furthermore assuming the typical FWHM for the LBGs in Capak+2015 of 250 km/s, we derive peak flux of 2.1 mJy (taking into account that our sources are unresolved). To properly sample the line, we require a S/N=3 in 50 km/s bands (S/N>5 for the integrated line), we therefore ask for a RMS of 0.69 mJy. We cover the ~99% redshift probability window in only 3 tunings. We have investigated the option of performing a frequency scan but we find that, for these short scans, searching for the line in separate science goals is more efficient.
While our main science goal is to detect [CII], we will also put upper limits on the dust content and determine if indeed UV selected high-redshift galaxies have very low levels of dust, i.e. LIR<~0.1LUV (Capak+2015).

For reference, the sources targeted by Capak+2015 have [CII] line fluxes in the range 0.29-1.95, for SFRs in the range 18-169, indicating our numbers are realistic.
Furthermore assuming the typical FWHM for the LBGs in Capak+2015 of 250 km/s, we derive peak flux of 2.1 mJy (taking into account that our sources are unresolved). To properly sample the line, we require a S/N=3 in 50 km/s bands (S/N>5 for the integrated line), we therefore ask for a RMS of 0.69 mJy. We cover the ~99% redshift probability window in only 3 tunings. We have investigated the option of performing a frequency scan but we find that, for these short scans, searching for the line in separate science goals is more efficient.
While our main science goal is to detect [CII], we will also put upper limits on the dust content and determine if indeed UV selected high-redshift galaxies have very low levels of dust, i.e. LIR<~0.1LUV (Capak+2015).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect a FWHM of 200-250 km/s so the coarsest spectral resolution is sufficient.

To properly sample the line, we require a S/N=3 in 50 km/s bands (S/N>5 for the integrated line), we therefore ask for a RMS of 0.69 mJy. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: To characterize the sources that are responsible for the reionization of the universe we are faced with two important challenges: I) due to the absorption of Lya photons by the intervening intergalactic medium, spectroscopic confirmations of galaxies at redshifts higher than z>6.5 are extremely rare and II) the stellar masses and ages of z>5.5 galaxies are subject to a few key degeneracies, including the unknown impact of emission lines on the derived masses and the well-known degeneracy between age and dust. We propose to resolve these two challenges with a small sample of three bright galaxies at z~6.8, 800 Myr after the Big Bang, from the CLASH and CANDELS surveys. Our excellent constraints on the redshift probability distribution, due to the observed brightness and blue Spitzer/IRAC colors which pinpoint the sources at z~6.7-6.8, enable a highly efficient search for [CII] during the crucial phase of late reionization (750-900 Myr after the Big Bang). The constraints on the dust content will resolve both degeneracies in our sample and result in accurate age and stellar mass measurements, since the Spitzer/IRAC 4.5m band at redshift z~6.8 is free of emission line contamination.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: University of California Observatories/Lick Observatory, California at Santa Cruz, University of
